results.title: Marriott Hacking Exposes Data of Up to 500 Million Guests
results.abstract: The personal information of customers at its Starwood hotels, including names, dates of birth, passport numbers and payment numbers could be at risk, the chain said.
results.byline: By NICOLE PERLROTH, AMIE TSANG and ADAM SATARIANO

multimedia.caption: Marriott International acknowledged on Friday that an “unauthorized party had copied and encrypted information” belonging to about 500 million customers on its Starwood reservations system.
Marriott International acknowledged on Friday that an “unauthorized party had copied and encrypted information” belonging to about 500 million customers on its Starwood reservations system.

results.title: Microsoft Is Worth as Much as Apple. How Did That Happen?
results.abstract: Just a few years ago, Microsoft was seen as a lumbering has-been. Now it’s a contender for the title of the world’s most valuable company.

multimedia.caption: Microsoft’s stock price has nearly tripled since Satya Nadella became chief executive in 2014.
Microsoft’s stock price has nearly tripled since Satya Nadella became chief executive in 2014.

results.title: Menial Tasks, Slurs and Swastikas: Many Black Workers at Tesla Say They Faced Racism
results.abstract: African-American workers have reported threats, humiliation and barriers to promotion at the plant. The automaker says there is no pattern of bias.

multimedia.caption: Demetric Diaz, left, and his father, Owen, said they had heard racial slurs directed toward them while working at the Tesla factory in Fremont, Calif.

results.title: The Week in Tech: Facebook’s Three Big Problems
results.abstract: The social media company is facing plenty of issues. Kevin Roose wonders how many of its executives understand that Facebook has more than just a P.R. crisis.

multimedia.caption: A chair was left empty for Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, in London on Tuesday when nine nations convened a hearing on Facebook’s practices.

results.title: Marketing Through Smart Speakers? Brands Don’t Need to Be Asked Twice
results.abstract: Google Home and Amazon Echo don’t carry paid advertising, so companies are trying more creative ways of using them to reach consumers.

results.title: Do You Know What You’re Breathing?
results.abstract: As distrust in the government grows, personal pollution monitors are the hot gift this holiday season.

results.title: Grindr President Defends Same-Sex Marriage Comments After Backlash
results.abstract: Scott Chen, the president of the gay dating app, said his personal view of marriage as “between a man and a woman” did not contradict his support for same-sex marriage.
des_facet: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

results.title: Sheryl Sandberg Asked for Soros Research, Facebook Acknowledges
results.abstract: Facebook’s second in command wanted an examination of the billionaire’s financial ties after he delivered a blistering speech about tech companies.
results.byline: By NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and MATTHEW ROSENBERG

multimedia.caption: Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s chief operating officer, wanted to know whether George Soros stood to gain from criticizing the company, according to people with knowledge of an email she sent.

results.title: Floyd Mayweather and DJ Khaled Are Fined in I.C.O. Crackdown
results.abstract: The boxer and the rapper did not disclose that they were paid $150,000 to promote Centra’s virtual currency last year. Regulators announced charges against them on Thursday.

multimedia.caption: Floyd Mayweather Jr. with DJ Khaled after an N.B.A. game in 2016. They admitted no wrongdoing in paying S.E.C. fines.

results.title: NASA Chooses Private Companies for Future Moon Landings

results.title: G.M.’s President Will Take Over Its Self-Driving Effort
results.abstract: The executive, Dan Ammann, is becoming chief executive of Cruise, which General Motors bought in 2016 to develop and commercialize autonomous cars.

multimedia.caption: Dan Ammann, right, will take over as chief executive of Cruise, the autonomous-vehicle unit of General Motors. Dan Kan, left, is the unit’s chief operating officer, and Kyle Vogt will now be its president and chief technology officer.

results.title: That Virus Alert on Your Computer? Scammers in India May Be Behind It
results.abstract: The police outside New Delhi raided fake tech-support centers that sent false warnings to Americans and Canadians and then charged to “fix” the nonexistent infection.
results.byline: By VINDU GOEL and SUHASINI RAJ

results.title: Virgos Are Queen of Teen Internet
results.abstract: Insights from Tumblr and others suggest that people really are obsessed with astrology (again) — and not just the memes.

results.title: Make Your Friends and Family Less Irksome This Holiday Season
results.abstract: Getting a big group together this time of year can be a hassle. So spare everyone the endless phone notifications and email threads and try these methods instead.

results.title: Covering a White House Where News Is Always Just a Tap Away
results.abstract: Katie Rogers’s beat is full of real-time digital moments. One tip to keep on top of it: If you call insiders from a blocked number, they’ll think you’re the White House and answer.

results.title: How to Survive the Next Era of Tech (Slow Down and Be Mindful)
results.abstract: In his final State of the Art column, Farhad Manjoo reflects on the industry’s changes and presents a new guide for navigating the future of technology.

results.title: New Zealand Blocks Huawei, in Blow to Chinese Telecom Giant
results.abstract: The announcement came a day after Papua New Guinea said it would uphold a deal with Huawei, illustrating the growing global divide over the risks of Chinese technology.

multimedia.caption: New Zealand rejected a proposal to use technology from Huawei, the Chinese telecom giant, to build its next-generation mobile data network, citing “significant national security risks.”

results.title: A Hot Seat for Facebook, an Empty Chair for Zuckerberg and a Vow to Share Secret Files
results.abstract: At a hearing in London, officials from nine countries criticized the social network and said they planned to release internal Facebook documents soon.

results.title: Jack Ma, China’s Richest Man, Belongs to the Communist Party. Of Course.
results.abstract: Many business figures join the organization out of expedience. Likewise, the party sees benefits in associating itself with capitalist success stories.

results.title: More Small Companies Avoid I.P.O.s, Sapping U.S. Economy’s Vitality
results.abstract: Small and midsize firms are increasingly steering clear of going public, giving big companies outsize influence over stock markets and hampering business creation, wage growth and productivity.
results.byline: By ERIN GRIFFITH and MATT PHILLIPS

multimedia.caption: Bill McDermott, the chief executive of SAP, in sunglasses, and Ryan Smith, the chief executive of Qualtrics, rang the closing bell in November at the New York Stock Exchange. Qualtrics agreed to sell itself to SAP rather than go through with a planned initial public offering.

results.title: General Kicked Off Facebook Can Still Glorify Military at Grandiose Museum
results.abstract: The colossal museum built by Myanmar’s military to honor itself and its leader showcases the mind-set of a force obsessed with its reputation. A critic calls it “a sign of their megalomania.”

multimedia.caption: In an exhibition recounting Myanmar’s martial history, the portrait of Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing hangs at the top of a pyramid of military leaders.
